name: improview
summary: improview is an early-stage project centered on LeetCode-related content with no implemented languages, frameworks, or runtimes yet. The README teases upcoming updates, including friendly robots tidying the docs, a full tour, and an invitation to star the repo.

name: ilikeyacut
summary: ilikeyacut is a native iOS mobile app monorepo for virtual hairstyle try-ons powered by Gemini's nano banana (Flash Image 2.5). It uses a serverless backend on AWS Lambda orchestrated via AWS SAM templates (Serverless Application Model) to deliver scalable, mobile-first beautytech experiences.

name: wallcrawler
summary: Wallcrawler is a self-hosted, AWS‑backed remote browser platform enabling Stagehand-powered LLM browsing and offering Browserbase-compatible APIs. It ships a TypeScript/Node SDK, Playwright integration, and multi-arch Docker images orchestrated via AWS CDK, Lambda, ECS/Fargate, API Gateway, EventBridge, DynamoDB, and S3 for session metadata, persisted contexts, and lifecycle management.

name: jobseek
summary: Jobseek automates job search across multiple job boards by orchestrating Wallcrawler-based headless browser automation and session management for scalable scraping and extraction. It’s a Next.js 15 app (Node.js) organized as a pnpm workspace with AWS CDK-based infrastructure, integrating Wallcrawler SDK and Anthropic API, exposing API routes to start searches, stream progress via Server-Sent Events, and manage sessions.

name: rubiks-cube
summary: Rubiks Cube State Management is a React/Next.js web app styled with TailwindCSS that renders a dynamic 2D flattened Rubik’s cube and exposes a face-labeled state with fixed coordinates for debugging. Rotation logic is implemented per-face via distinct transforms; the initial cube state is generated programmatically through loops and a helper function; testing uses Jest with coverage for all face rotations (including inverted rotations); the app is bootstrapped with create-next-app and deployable to GitHub Pages.

name: portfolio
summary: portfolio is a full-stack Next.js 15 App Router site with streaming server components and a TailwindCSS-based component library, deployed on AWS via a CDK-based infra using OpenNext packaging and served from S3 behind CloudFront with Lambda@Edge SSR. It features GitHub-sourced projects with offline summaries, an OpenAI-powered chat assistant leveraging precomputed repo knowledge, a blog with Markdown and frontmatter, and an admin area secured by Auth.js/OAuth, all coordinated through GitHub Actions and a comprehensive deployment workflow.

name: AWS-IAM-Projects
summary: Polaris-driven UX mock of a new IAM Console built for the Web using React, focusing on the Users entity. The prototype leverages AWS IAM APIs to demonstrate a React-based console experience with Polaris UI framework integration for IAM.

name: slash-siege
summary: slash-siege is a web-based, multiplayer stick-figure fighter hosted on GitHub Pages, enabling browser-based real-time battles. Development is organized with a Trello board and tested at the project's GitHub Pages URL (volpestyle.github.io/slash-siege/).

name: AED-Sheets
summary: Audio Engineering Discrepancy Logger is a MEAN-stack web application (MongoDB, Express.js, Angular, Node.js) built for NPR to log, search, and manage incidents and technical logs, with subscription-based alerts and automatic IT ticket creation. It includes automatic NPR employee provisioning, role-based access control, and both personal and global subscriptions delivering email or SMS notifications.

name: personal-website-v1
summary: A personal website and portfolio hosted as a static site on AWS using an S3 bucket with CloudFront CDN. It serves as a static website for internship applications and showcases web development work.

name: Parse-Tree-Calculator
summary: Parse-Tree-Calculator is a web-based scientific calculator that evaluates expressions using a parse-tree to enforce operator precedence, supporting decimals, nested parentheses, and trig functions via a stack-driven evaluation approach. Built with HTML, SASS, and vanilla JavaScript, it tokenizes input, builds a parse tree, and applies explicit multiplication rules to ensure correct, in-browser evaluation.
